title: 112_s3300
content: The Act may be cited as the "Manhattan Project National Historical Park Act". The Manhattan Project was a top-secret program during WWII to create an atomic bomb before Nazi Germany. Experts recommended establishing nationally significant sites for preservation and public interpretation. The Manhattan Project National Historical Park Study Act directed the Secretary of the Interior to conduct a special resource study of historically significant sites associated with the Manhattan Project. The National Park Service study found that including these sites in the national park system would enhance protection, preservation, and public understanding of this significant story in American history. The Department of the Interior, with the Department of Energy's approval, recommended creating a Manhattan Project National Historical Park at Oak Ridge, Los Alamos, and Hanford. This designation would improve preservation, interpretation, and access to the historically significant resources related to the Manhattan Project for current and future generations to understand its complex legacy. The Manhattan Project has a significant, far-reaching, and complex legacy. The Manhattan Project has a significant, far-reaching, and complex legacy. The purpose of the project is outlined in Section 3. The Manhattan Project's legacy is outlined in Section 3 of the Act, which aims to preserve and protect its historic resources for future generations, improve public understanding, enhance access to the Historical Park, and support preservation efforts by various organizations and individuals. The Manhattan Project National Historical Park, established under section 5, defines key terms such as "Historical Park" and "Manhattan Project" as well as the role of the Secretary of the Interior. The Manhattan Project National Historical Park is established as a unit of the National Park System, including areas in Oak Ridge, Tennessee, and Los Alamos, New Mexico. The Manhattan Project National Historical Park includes facilities in Los Alamos, New Mexico (Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory National Historic Landmark District, former East Cafeteria, former dormitory) and in Hanford, Washington (B Reactor National Historic Landmark, Hanford High School). The Manhattan Project National Historical Park includes various historic sites in Hanford, Washington such as Hanford High School, Hanford Construction Camp Historic District, White Bluffs Bank building, Bruggemann's Agricultural Complex warehouse, Hanford Irrigation District Pump House, and the T Plant (221-T Process Building). The Manhattan Project National Historical Park in Hanford, Washington includes various historic sites such as Hanford High School, Hanford Construction Camp Historic District, White Bluffs Bank building, Bruggemann's Agricultural Complex warehouse, Hanford Irrigation District Pump House, and the T Plant (221-T Process Building). SEC. 6. AGREEMENT. The Secretary and the Secretary of Energy will enter into an agreement regarding the administration of facilities within the Historical Park, including provisions for public access, management, interpretation, and historic preservation. The Secretary will have decision-making authority for historic interpretation of the Manhattan Project within the park. The agreement between the Secretary and the Secretary of Energy will ensure the appropriate role of the National Park Service in preserving historic resources. The Secretary of Energy will be responsible for protecting public safety, national security, and the ongoing mission of the Department of Energy at specific sites. Additionally, they may consult on historical information related to the Manhattan Project and retain responsibility for environmental remediation and structural safety. The agreement under subsection (a) may be amended to add Historical Park facilities, land, or interests in land under the jurisdiction of the Secretary of Energy. SEC. 7. PUBLIC PARTICIPATION. The Secretary must consult with State, county, and local officials, organizations, and the public before executing agreements or developing management plans. Within 30 days of executing an agreement, the Secretary must publish a notice in the Federal Register establishing the Historical Park with an official boundary map available for public inspection. Any land or facility acquired within eligible areas must be included in the agreement. Any land or facility acquired within eligible areas must be added to the Historical Park. SEC. 8. ADMINISTRATION. The Secretary administers the Historical Park in accordance with applicable laws, including the National Park System Organic Act and the Act of August 21, 1935. A general management plan must be completed within 3 years of funding availability. Interpretive tours of historically significant Manhattan may be provided by the Secretary. The Secretary may acquire land within eligible areas for the Historical Park through transfer of jurisdiction, purchase, donation, or exchange. Land may also be acquired for visitor and administrative facilities. Donations and cooperative agreements for federal facilities are allowed. The Secretary may enter agreements with Federal agencies to provide public access to Manhattan Project resources. Donations and cooperative agreements with various entities can further the purpose of these agreements. The Secretary may offer technical assistance for managing and preserving historically significant Manhattan Project resources. Additionally, donations to the Department of Energy can be made for this purpose. The Secretary of the Department of Energy can accept gifts, bequests, and devises to preserve historically significant resources related to the Department.
